Package jetbrains.exodus.io

Interface DataWriter

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.io.Closeable
    public interface DataWriter
extends java.io.Closeable
    DataWriter defines the way how data is written to Log, how blocks appear in the log and how they are removed from the log. Log blocks can be mutable and immutable. All blocks having length equal to maximum log block size are immutable. In any moment, only one block can be mutable. This has maximum address. DataWriter always writes to a single mutable block, that makes log appendable.
    Since:
    1.3.0
    See Also:
    Block, DataReader, DataReaderWriterProvider

    • Method Detail

      • isOpen

        boolean isOpen()
        Returns true is the DataWriter is open. i.e. there is an incomplete mutable block having length less than maximum log block size.
        Returns:
        true is the DataWriter is open

      • write

        Block write​(byte[] b,
            int off,
            int len)
        Writes (appends) binary data to Log. Returns new Block instance representing mutable block.
        Parameters:
        b - binary data array
        off - starting offset in the array
        len - number of byte to write
        Returns:
        mutable Block instance
        See Also:
        Block

      • sync

        void sync()
        If applicable, forces flush of written data to underlying storage device. Transaction durability depends on the implementation of this method.

      • syncDirectory

        void syncDirectory()
        If applicable, forces flush of changes in directory structure to underlying storage device.

      • close

        void close()
        Closes the data writer. Log closes the data writer each time when mutable block becomes immutable, i.e. reaches its maximum log block size.
        Specified by:
        close in interface java.lang.AutoCloseable
        Specified by:
        close in interface java.io.Closeable

      • clear

        void clear()
        Clears Log by location specified as a parameter to DataReaderWriterProvider.newReaderWriter(String). The database becomes empty.

      • openOrCreateBlock

        Block openOrCreateBlock​(long address,
                        long length)
        Open existing block for writing or creates the new one by specified address with specified length. This method is used in the log recovery procedure, so DataWriter should truncate existing block if its physical length is greater than specified one. This method is always applied to a mutable block.
        Parameters:
        address - address of block to open or create
        length - valid block length
        Returns:
        mutable Block instance

      • removeBlock

        void removeBlock​(long blockAddress,
                 @NotNull
                 @NotNull RemoveBlockType rbt)
        Removes existing immutable block. If applicable, this method can rename block (file on a file system) instead of removing it if specified RemoveBlockType rbt is equal to RemoveBlockType.Rename.
        Parameters:
        blockAddress - address of block to remove
        rbt - RemoveBlockType.Rename to rename block instead of removing it.
        See Also:
        RemoveBlockType

      • truncateBlock

        @Deprecated
void truncateBlock​(long blockAddress,
                   long length)
        Deprecated.
        data files are not designed to be truncated
        Truncates existing block to specified length. Does nothing is specified length is greater than or equal to physical block length.
        Parameters:
        blockAddress - address of block to truncate
        length - block length

      • lock

        boolean lock​(long timeout)
        If applicable, tries to acquire writer's lock in specified time. If the lock is acquired, returns true. Successfully acquired lock guarantees that Log cannot be opened in parallel (within same JVM or not) unless it is released by the writer.
        Parameters:
        timeout - - time to wait for lock acquisition
        Returns:
        true if the lock is acquired
        See Also:
        release(), lockInfo()

      • release

        boolean release()
        Releases writer's lock.
        Returns:
        true if released successfully
        See Also:
        lock(long)

      • lockInfo

        java.lang.String lockInfo()
        For debugging purposes, returns detailed information about current lock owner. If lock(long) return false, Log throws an ExodusException with the lock info in its message.
        Returns:
        Human-readable information about lock owner
        See Also:
        lock(long)

      • asyncWrite

        jetbrains.exodus.core.dataStructures.Pair<Block,​java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture<jetbrains.exodus.core.dataStructures.LongIntPair>> asyncWrite​(byte[] b,
                                                                                                                                                           int off,
                                                                                                                                                           int len)
        Asynchronously writes binary data to Log. Returns new Block instance representing mutable block and completable future which will be executed once asynchronous write was executed. This method is not thread safe and can not be used by multiple threads without external synchronization.
        Parameters:
        b - binary data array
        off - starting offset in the array
        len - number of byte to write
        Returns:
        Pair which consist of mutable Block instance and completable future which services as indicator of completion (successful or unsuccessful) of requested write. Result of execution of completable future are: start address of the position where data is written and amount of data was written in bytes.
        Since:
        3.0
        See Also:
        Block

      • position

        long position()
        Return current position of writer inside the file. This method is not thread safe and can not be used without external synchronization.
        Returns:
        current position of writer inside the file.
        Since:
        3.0
